case_vignette: A 23-year-old G1P0 with a history of epilepsy gives birth to a male infant at 33 weeks gestation. The mother had no prenatal care and took no prenatal vitamins. The infant appears somnolent and is not crying. The child’s temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 30/min. On physical examination in the delivery room, the child has a membranous pouch extruding over the thoracolumbar spine. His lower extremities are flaccid. A brain MRI is shown in Figure A.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Yes, I was born prematurely at 33 weeks gestation.
Final Diagnosis: Premature Infant Sleep Apnea Syndrome (PISAS).
